q1.value: Time Perception, Mental States and Productivity

q3.value: Sometimes, there is a discrepancy between the time we experience and the real time. Mental states influence our time perception: time seems to fly when we are having fun, but seems to drag when we are bored. But time perception in its turn also influences our mental states. When time appears to elapse slower, people feel more bored and when time seems to elapse faster, people feel more stimulated or engaged. This other way around is what we know little about and what is of interest in this research project. To go to the main theory, it is suggested that time perception affects productivity. Speeding up and slowing down the clock speed corresponds respectively to increased and decreased task speed. However, when time appears to elapse slower people feel more bored and when people are more bored they are less productive. To clarify which explanation (direct, indirect or shared effect) is more likely, I will investigate the relationship between time perception and productivity. Specifically, I test whether mental states (i.e. boredom and task-enjoyment) as mechanisms (also) explain this relationship or if it is solely time perception that directly affects productivity.

q4.value:
The main hypothesis is that the two mental states (i.e. boredom and task-enjoyment) mediate the relationship between time perception and productivity. In more detail, for the participants getting the 15-minutes instruction I hypothesise that, compared to the control condition: 1) they experience the time as elapsing slower, 2) they report more feelings of boredom and less feelings of task-enjoyment, 3) they produce less work of less quality. For the participants getting the 35-minutes instruction I hypothesise that, compared to the control condition: 1) they experience the time as elapsing faster, 2) they report more feelings of task-enjoyment and less feelings of boredom, 3) they produce more work of more quality.

I have no specific hypotheses to what extent mental states mediate the relationship between time perception and productivity.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Procedure
There is a pilot test first. Six volunteers are tested to ensure the task with its manipulation and the questionnaire (technically) work. Before starting testing participants, I first request them to take off their watches and bracelets and put smartphones back. I say that this is because it could distract them from making the task. In fact, the real hidden reason is to ensure the time manipulation works, as wearing a watch could disrupt this. It actually does not matter if participants wear bracelets. However, if I only state that they are not allowed to wear a watch, it could be the case that some participants get aware of the time manipulation.

In the instruction, it is stressed to the participants that it does not matter if they cannot complete the task, because this is not the aim. In reality, all participants get 25 minutes to work on the task. However, they get different instructions on how much time they get: 15 minutes (slow condition), 25 minutes (control condition) or 35 minutes (fast condition). A virtual clock on the computer screen is manipulated in order to display the instructed amount of minutes elapsing. After the task, participants have to fill out a questionnaire.

Instruments
All participants make the same test and questionnaire in a cubicle in the lab of Radboud University. The task that will be used is a new developed task for the Behavioural Science Institute and will be used in other research projects too. In the task, participants have to re-type a text as presented in a file. Meanwhile, revised and unrevised mistakes (quality) and type speed (quantity) are measured and automatically saved on the computer. The mistakes and type speed are unknown to the participants themselves, so they cannot change their behaviour because of this feedback. The questionnaire that will be used is a truncated version of the Job Boredom Scale by Lee et al. (1986) with some added questions about task-enjoyment. Since I want to measure boredom as a state during the task and not during a job, I rephrased the items (e.g. I was bored during the task). Responses will be given on a scale from 1 = disagree to 5 = agree.

q9.value:
To randomise, I will use the online random number generator on the following website to randomly assign 50 subjects to 3 groups: https://www.graphpad.com/quickcalcs/. 

Group A = fast condition (35-minutes instruction). 
Group B = slow condition (15-minutes instruction). 
Group C = control group (25-minutes instruction).

Explanation from the website:
The random number generator is seeded with the time of day, so it works differently each time you use it. Each subject is first assigned to a group nonrandomly. Then the assignment of each subject is swapped with the group assignment of a randomly chosen subject. This should suffice, but the entire process is repeated twice to make sure it is really random. Note that you can copy and paste the values from the web page into Excel.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: All participants must have a sufficient English comprehension and be able to read the text from the computer screen. These criteria are stated when recruiting participants and checked prior to the start of the task. Data from participants who were aware of the time manipulation will be deleted. All participants are asked afterwards what she or he thinks was the manipulation. Errors will be deleted as well. This includes technical errors and impossible responses, such as a complete re-typed text within only a few seconds. Missings are not possible in this study design as all questions have to be answered.

q13.value: I aim to recruit 150 participants in total: 50 participants per condition

q14.value:
Since I use path analyses, the sample size is based on the number of parameters in my conceptual model instead of a power analysis (Klein, 1998). Having 14 parameters multiplying by 10 indicates 140 cases. In addition, Hoyle (1995) recommends a sample size between 100 and 200 in order to have confidence in the goodness-of-fit test. I aim to recruit 150 participants since this number is close to 140 and in between 100 and 200. In addition, 150 participants can equally be divided into three conditions, while this is not possible with for example 140 participants.

Paying each participant €5 and having a limited budget of €600 allows me to recruit maximally 120 participants for money and minimally 30 participants for course credits (0.5). The participants will be recruited via the research participation system SONA.

q15.value: Data collection will take place in February and March 2020 and will either stop when 150 participants have participated or beginning of April.

question.value:
Independent variables: time perception conditions. In reality, all participants get 25 minutes to work on the task. However, they get different instructions on how much time they get: 15 minutes (slow condition), 25 minutes (control condition) or 35 minutes (fast condition). A virtual clock on the computer screen is manipulated in order to display the instructed amount of minutes elapsing. It is assumed that participants in the different conditions get different time perceptions because of the time manipulation. This assumption will be checked after finishing the task.

IV1 = 15-minutes instruction or 'slow' condition
IV2 = 35-minutes instruction or 'fast' condition

(both conditions will be compared to the control condition)

Dependent variables: qualitative and quantitative productivity. All participants make the same task in a cubicle in the lab of Radboud University. In the task, participants have to re-type a text as presented in a file. Meanwhile, revised and unrevised mistakes (quality) and type speed (quantity) are measured and automatically saved on the computer. The mistakes and type speed are unknown to the participants themselves, so they cannot change their behaviour because of this feedback.

Independent variables: time perception conditions. In reality, all participants get 25 minutes to work on the task. However, they get different instructions on how much time they get: 15 minutes (slow condition), 25 minutes (control condition) or 35 minutes (fast condition). A virtual clock on the computer screen is manipulated in order to display the instructed amount of minutes elapsing. It is assumed that participants in the different conditions get different time perceptions because of the time manipulation. This assumption will be checked after finishing the task.

Mediators: boredom and task-enjoyment. After the task, participants will fill out a questionnaire. This is a truncated version of the Job Boredom Scale by Lee et al. (1986) with some added questions about task-enjoyment. Since I want to measure boredom as a state during the task and not during a job, I rephrased the items (e.g. I was bored during the task). Responses are given on a scale from 1 = disagree to 5 = agree.

Overview:
DV1 = mistakes
DV2 = type speed
IV1 = 15-minutes instruction or 'slow' time perception condition (will be compard to the control condtion)
IV2 = 35-minutes instruction or 'fast' time perception condition (will be compared to the control condition)
M1 = reported feelings of boredom
M2 = reported feelings of task-enjoyment

All data-analyses will be conducted in the R program. The dependent variables mistakes (quality aspect) and type speed (quantity aspect) will be analysed in two ways: per minute and in total. For mistakes in total and overall type speed, I will use path analyses within the lavaan function. For mistakes per minute and type speed per minute, I will make use of time series analyses.

The following will be tested:
-	The main effect of time perception conditions on qualitative and quantitative productivity. 
-	The main effects of time perception conditions on boredom and task-enjoyment. 
-	The main effects of boredom and task-enjoyment on qualitative and quantitative productivity. 
-	Mediation effect: do boredom and/or task-enjoyment mediate the relationship between time perception conditions and qualitative and quantitative productivity.

q22.value: Data from participants who were aware of the time manipulation will be deleted. All participants are asked afterwards what she or he thinks was the manipulation. Errors will be deleted as well. This includes technical errors and impossible responses, such as a complete re-typed text within only a few seconds.

q23.value: Missings are not possible in this study design as all questions have to be answered.

q25.value: Nine additional questions are added to the questionnaire serving as a pilot-test for a researcher colleague. These questions measure the following constructs: cognitive fatigue, stress, effort, engagement, frustration and cognitive demands.

attributes.title: Custom-made Chatbots 2019/2020
attributes.description: Our research will investigate the following research question: To what extent does user chatbot customization (IV) influence the user’s trust (DV) in the chatbot? We hypothesize that users who customize the chatbot will report greater trust in the chatbot after interacting with it than users who interact with a non-customized chatbot.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value:
Custom-made Chatbots - 2019/2020

This experimental research will investigate the following research question: To what extent does user chatbot customization (IV) influence the user’s trust (DV) in the chatbot? We hypothesize that users who customize the chatbot will report greater trust in the chatbot after interacting with it than users who interact with a non-customized chatbot.

other.value:
The questionnaire will assess the same general characteristics of the participant as previously given/determined for the chatbot, namely gender,
nationality, and personal interests. Furthermore, the experimenter will note down key information of the participant's outward appearance (i.e. brighter/darker skin, blue/green/brown eyes, red/blond/dark hair). We assess all of this information of the participant to look at similarities between the user and the chatbot in an exploratory
manner. Furthermore, the questionnaire will include information about the user’s intent for potential chatbot design implications. The analysis of the answers will not be guided by any specific hypotheses.

sample.value:
We aim to recruit 60 participants per condition (N = 120) through an online research participation system and manual promotion on campus and on social
media. This number is based on a G*Power Analysis with a small to medium effect size and the limited resources of this project.

analyses.value:
Confirmatory Factor Analyses (CFA) will be conducted for the self-report scales. To analyze the final scores, a linear model that controls for the participant’s technological attitude (i.e. user intent and previous chatbot experience) will be performed. The general model structure will look as follows:
lm(trust ~ (ICC + Anthropomorphism) * condition)
For all statistical procedures the software environment for statistical computing and graphics R will be used; more specifically the package lavaan for running the CFAs and the package lme4 (version 1.1.21) for the linear model.

outliers.value: We will exclude participants (1) who show a deviating response time (e.g. no response at all or unusually long), (2) who, judged by the principal researcher being present for the chatbot conversation, do not take the experimental task seriously and show inappropriate conversational behavior (e.g. typing incoherent sentences), and (3) who do not pass the manipulation check or have an impossible completion time of the questionnaire (e.g. skipping the chatroom).

dependent.value: Our dependent variable will be the trust in the chatbot. In this research trust is defined as the sum of expectations that natural and moral social orders persist and that one's counterpart is technically competent as well as fiduciarily responsible, meaning that one’s counterpart is able to put other's interests before its own.

conditions.value:
The participants will be pseudo-randomly assigned to either the experimental or control condition, with only the former allowing customization of the chatbot. Customization will be realized through options in the online questionnaire, through which the participant customizes visual (i.e. brighter/darker skin, blue/green/brown eyes, red/blond/dark hair) as well as factual characteristics (i.e. name, gender, nationality, and interests) of the chatbot.

Experimental Condition: 1. demographics, 2. customization of chatbot, 3. conversation with chatbot, 4. outcome measures (incl. manipulation check and
debriefing)
Control Condition: 1. demographics, 2. introduction of existing chatbot "Mitsuku", 3. conversation with chatbot, 4. outcome measures (incl. manipulation check and debriefing)

The chatbot conversation will be monitored by the experimenter in both conditions. Necessary adjustments to the original answers of the chatbot in the experimental condition will be made according to a standardized profile sheet (see additional upload) that is based on a series of pilot conversations prior to data collection. The response time of the chatbot's messages to the participant will be kept as equal as possible between both conditions.

hypothesis.value:
Our research will investigate the following research question: To what extent does user chatbot customization (IV) influence the user’s trust (DV) in the chatbot? We hypothesize that users who customize the chatbot will report greater trust in the chatbot after interacting with it than users who interact with a non-customized chatbot.
The interaction will be in form of a tex-based conversation with the existing conversational open-source chatbot "Mitsuku" created from AIML (Artificial Intelligence Markup Language) technology. This conversation will take place in a chatroom on a specifically designed website (through www.wix.com). The principal researcher accesses this chatroom via the website's backend and copies and pastes the messages between the participant and Mitsuku back and forth along the Wizard of Oz approach. All conversations will be deleted after checking the average response time. No conversational data will be stored or analyzed.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

attributes.title: Stranger to my face
attributes.description: Stranger to my face: top-down and bottom-up effects underlying prioritization of images of one’s face

summary.value: Raw data and experimental materials for three experiments conducted for "Stranger to my face" research project

registration_responses.summary: Raw data and experimental materials for three experiments conducted for "Stranger to my face" research project

q1.value: QJE-STD-19-254.R2 - On the time it takes to judge grammaticality

q3.value: The presentation duration of 5-word sequences was varied and participants were asked to judge their grammaticality. The 5-word sequences were presented for a variable duration randomly selected between 50ms and 500ms with 50ms steps and were immediately followed by a masking stimulus. Half of the sequences were correct sentences which were randomly intermixed with ungrammatical sequences formed of the same words in scrambled order. We measured the proportion of correct responses for each presentation duration in the grammatical and ungrammatical conditions, and calculated sensitivity and bias from these measures. Both the sensitivity measure (d’) and the probability correct responses to grammatical and ungrammatical sequences increased as stimulus duration increased, with a d’ of 2 and an average percent correct close to 87% for the grammatical sequences already attained at 300ms. The rate of increase in performance diminished beyond 300ms.  Grammatical decision times were faster and more accurate for the grammatically correct sequences, thus indicating that participants were not responding by detecting illegal word combinations in the ungrammatical sequences. On the basis of these findings we provide an upper estimate of 300ms as the time it takes to access reliable syntactic information from 5-word sequences in French, and we discuss the implications of this constraint for models of reading.

q4.value: In the present work we used a data-limited version of the grammatical decision task, as opposed to the response-limited version used in our prior work. Thus, rather than examining RTs to word sequences that remain on screen until response, here we examined accuracy in responding to word sequences that remained on screen for a variable amount of time and were immediately followed by a backward mask. Directly relevant for the present study is another data-limited paradigm that has been used in several recent studies. This is the Rapid Parallel Visual Presentation (RPVP) technique whereby a sequence of words is presented for a brief duration (200ms) and followed by a pattern mask and a positional cue for identification of one word in the sequence (Snell & Grainger, 2017; Wen et al., 2019). In these studies, we once again compared grammatically correct sequences (e.g., the boy can run) with ungrammatical scrambled sequences of the same words (e.g., run boy the can), and the target was the same word at the same position in both sequences (“boy” in these examples). We found that word identification was more accurate in the grammatical sequences than the ungrammatical sequences – a sentence superiority effect.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

question.value: One hundred participants (75 female) were recruited at Aix-Marseille University, France. They were all native French speakers and received either course credit or monetary compensation (€10/hour). The participants reported normal or correct-to-normal vision and ranged in age from 18 to 26 years (M = 22.07, SD = 2.77). They were naïve as to the purpose of the experiment and signed an informed consent form before starting the experiment. Ethics approval was obtained from the Comité de Protection des Personnes SUD-EST IV (No. 17/051).

q13.value: The raw data were merged using R (R Core Team, 2017) and we rejected 14 participants due to low average performance (i.e., < 50 %). All the other participants (N = 86) performed with average accuracy equal to M = 73.32 % (SD = 44.22). The final dataset consisted of 10320 data points per condition, which is largely superior to the recommendation of Brysbaert and Stevens (2018).

registration_responses.q1: QJE-STD-19-254.R2 - On the time it takes to judge grammaticality
registration_responses.q3: The presentation duration of 5-word sequences was varied and participants were asked to judge their grammaticality. The 5-word sequences were presented for a variable duration randomly selected between 50ms and 500ms with 50ms steps and were immediately followed by a masking stimulus. Half of the sequences were correct sentences which were randomly intermixed with ungrammatical sequences formed of the same words in scrambled order. We measured the proportion of correct responses for each presentation duration in the grammatical and ungrammatical conditions, and calculated sensitivity and bias from these measures. Both the sensitivity measure (d’) and the probability correct responses to grammatical and ungrammatical sequences increased as stimulus duration increased, with a d’ of 2 and an average percent correct close to 87% for the grammatical sequences already attained at 300ms. The rate of increase in performance diminished beyond 300ms.  Grammatical decision times were faster and more accurate for the grammatically correct sequences, thus indicating that participants were not responding by detecting illegal word combinations in the ungrammatical sequences. On the basis of these findings we provide an upper estimate of 300ms as the time it takes to access reliable syntactic information from 5-word sequences in French, and we discuss the implications of this constraint for models of reading.
registration_responses.q4: In the present work we used a data-limited version of the grammatical decision task, as opposed to the response-limited version used in our prior work. Thus, rather than examining RTs to word sequences that remain on screen until response, here we examined accuracy in responding to word sequences that remained on screen for a variable amount of time and were immediately followed by a backward mask. Directly relevant for the present study is another data-limited paradigm that has been used in several recent studies. This is the Rapid Parallel Visual Presentation (RPVP) technique whereby a sequence of words is presented for a brief duration (200ms) and followed by a pattern mask and a positional cue for identification of one word in the sequence (Snell & Grainger, 2017; Wen et al., 2019). In these studies, we once again compared grammatically correct sequences (e.g., the boy can run) with ungrammatical scrambled sequences of the same words (e.g., run boy the can), and the target was the same word at the same position in both sequences (“boy” in these examples). We found that word identification was more accurate in the grammatical sequences than the ungrammatical sequences – a sentence superiority effect.

attributes.title: Isolating the locus of informational interference during speech-in-noise perception: word-form interference

q1.value: Isolating the locus of informational interference during speech-in-noise perception: word-form interference

q3.value:
Speech-in-noise (SiN) research typically distinguishes two types of masking caused by background noise: energetic masking (direct interference between the target speech and background noise in the cochlea) and informational masking (interference higher in the auditory pathway) [1]. We have coined the term "Inf-Int" to refer specifically to high-level informational masking involving linguistic and cognitive factors and which is influenced by long-term knowledge. For example, background speech in a known language is more distracting than background speech in an unfamiliar language [2]. Inf-Int is currently poorly understood, at least in part because it is extremely difficult to manipulate Inf-Int without altering lower-level informational masking or energetic masking.

This study aims to explore interference at the word-form level as one possible locus of Inf-Int. This will be achieved by using as a masker an artificial language similar to those typically used in statistical learning studies. Such languages comprise a continuous stream of syllables, with no acoustic cues to segmentation; however, the transition probabilities between adjacent syllables allow listeners to infer and learn the "words" which make up the language [3].

The study will involve 3 tasks: a training task and two subsequent SiN tasks. During the training task, listeners will be taught to recognise the "words" present in the artificial language. The two subsequent SiN tasks will require listeners to transcribe sentences presented in one of two types of background masker. In one SiN task, the masker will be derived from the trained artificial language. In the other SiN task, the masker will be derived from a random concatenation of syllables from the artifical language, but containing no "words" from the artificial language and no other regular structure.

We will therefore create a situation in which the background masker is highly similar across the two SiN tasks, but listeners are only aware of word forms in the masker in one of the two tasks. By comparing performance across the two SiN tasks, it should thus be possible to isolate any effect on speech-in-noise perception arising from word-form interference.

[1] Mattys, S. L., Davis, M. H., Bradlow, A. R., & Scott, S. K. (2012). Speech recognition in adverse conditions: A review. Language and Cognitive Processes, 27(7-8), 953-978.
[2] Van Engen, K. J., & Bradlow, A. R. (2007). Sentence recognition in native-and foreign-language multi-talker background noise. The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America, 121(1), 519-526.
[3] Palmer, S. D., & Mattys, S. L. (2016). Speech segmentation by statistical learning is supported by domain-general processes within working memory. The Quarterly Journal of Experimental Psychology, 69(12), 2390-2401.

q4.value: H1. Interference from recognisable word forms in a masker is required to give rise to Inf-Int. If this is the case, then scores from the SiN task featuring the artificial language masker will be poorer than those from the SiN task featuring the random masker.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Please see Design.pptx for full details of the study design.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Data will be collected in the lab.

Participants will be young adult native speakers of English, aged 18-30, with normal hearing (auditory thresholds of ≤ 25 dB HL in each ear at 0.5, 1, 2 and 4 kHz, as measured by an audiogram) and self-reported normal (or corrected-to-normal) vision. They will receive payment for their participation (£6/hr).

Recruitment will take place via internal departmental recruitment systems, advertisements on social media (e.g. Twitter, Facebook) and the researchers’ personal networks. This may be coupled with the posting of approved adverts on departmental poster boards within the University.

q14.value:
We will use generalised linear mixed models (GLMMs) to analyse our data. Power analysis for GLMMs is more complicated than for ANOVAs, in particular due to the need to estimate random variance/covariance parameters [1]. In an idea world, such a calculation would be based on existing data from a similar task/paradigm; for the current study, however, no such data exist. Nevertheless, as a rule-of-thumb, it has been suggested that a minimum of 1600 observations per condition is necessary to adequately power a mixed effects model [2]. Given 60 stimuli in a single condition (i.e. 60 stimuli in one of the two SiN tasks), we would therefore need 26-27 participants per group.

[1] Meteyard, L., & Davies, R. (2019, March 11). Best practice guidance for linear mixed-effects models in psychological science. https://doi.org/10.31234/osf.io/h3duq
[2] Brysbaert, M., & Stevens, M. (2018). Power Analysis and Effect Size in Mixed Effects Models: A Tutorial. Journal of Cognition, 1(1), 9. DOI: http://doi.org/10.5334/joc.10

question.value:
The only manipulated variable will be the nature of the background masker in the two SiN tasks.

In one SiN task, the background masker will feature the same artificial language that participants were trained on during the training task.

In the second SiN task, the background masker will feature the syllables comprising the artificial language, but in a random order (containing no "words" or partwords from the artificial language, and no other regular structure).

The order of presentation of these two SiN tasks will be counterbalanced across participants. The sentence set used in each SiN task will be counterbalanced across the two masker types.

The manipulated variable is therefore masker type, with two levels (artificial language/random).

After the training task, participants will complete a short auditory-only 2AFC task, in which they will be asked to identify which of two alternatives was an actual "word" from the artificial language. The number of correct responses will be recorded.

During each subsequent SiN task, participants will be asked to transcribe a set of target sentences presented in one of two masker types (artificial language/random). The number of keywords correct (0-5) for each sentence will be recorded for each SiN task.

After the SiN tasks, all participants will complete a second auditory-only 2AFC task to assess learning of the artificial language (as above). The number of correct responses will be recorded.

Our intention is to perform the main analysis at a trial-by-trial level, using as our outcome variable the number of keywords correct on a given trial of a given SiN task (e.g. 3/5). This does not require any combination of measures.

However, we will also use mean scores as rough indicators of performance. To derive these scores, we will first convert each trial score into a percentage (i.e. 3/5 = 60%), and then take the average of these percentages across the entire task for each participant. This will enable us to get a sense of each participant's overall performance (e.g. we can observe that a given participant scored on average 65% in the random masker condition and 55% in the artificial language masker condition). We will derive other relevant global measures (e.g. standard deviation) in the same way.

We will also derive global mean scores for each condition by averaging across each participant's overall performance on a given task. This will enable us to get a sense of general performance (e.g. we can observe that, on average, participants scored 72% in the random masker condition and 61% in the artificial language masker condition). We will derive other relevant global measures (e.g. standard deviation) in the same way.

Analyses will be carried out in R. To test H1, we will use a generalized linear mixed model (GLMM) with a binomial distribution and logit link. This allows us to model each single trial as a datapoint, with the outcome variable being the proportion correct out of a given number of total per-trial observations. In this case, the outcome variable will be the number of SiN keywords correct on a given trial (i.e. X/5 keywords correct). There will be one categorical predictor as a fixed effect: masker type (2 levels: artifical language, random). Participants will be included as random intercepts. Other random effects (e.g. item, sentence set) may be included if they improve model fit. Model fit will be assessed via likelihood ratio tests and AIC values; the effect of masker type will be assessed via likelihood ratio tests comparing the full model to a model without the fixed effect of masker type. Additionally, Bayesian analyses may be carried out to calculate a Bayes factor for the model in comparison to a reduced model containing no effect of masker type.

q20.value: It may be necessary to centre the averaged SiN scores to meaningfully compare overall performance across the different sentence sets. No dummy coding will be necessary for the categorical predictor variable: the packages in R that will be used to run the GLMMs (e.g. lme4) handle categorical variables without the need for dummy coding.

q21.value: Inferences will be made using frequentist statistics, where p less than 0.05 indicates a significant result. Alpha will be adjusted for multiple comparisons where necessary. Frequentist statistics may be supplemented with Bayesian statistics, where a Bayes factor of greater than 3 is interpreted as evidence in favour of the specified hypothesis and a Bayes factor of less than 1/3 as evidence in favour of the null hypothesis.

q22.value: Full datasets will be excluded for participants whose performance in the post-training and/or final 2AFC tasks indicates that they have not successfully learned the artificial language. (See Design.pptx for more details.)

q23.value: No missing data within included datasets is anticipated. However, GLMMs are able to handle missing data. As a result, data with some missing points can be included in the analysis (e.g. in the unlikely event of technical failure).

attributes.title: The Impact of Russian Election Meddling on Allies’ Trust in the United States: The Case of Japan

q1.value: The Impact of Russian Election Meddling on Allies’ Trust in the United States: The Case of Japan

q5.value: Horiuchi acknowledges financial support from the Dickey Center for International Un- derstanding at Dartmouth College.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: For Study 1 (Australia and the U.K.), please refer to the original EGAP submission, which includes a pre-analysis plan. • After observing some promising results from the two survey experiments in Australia and the United Kingdom (hereafter, Study 1), we decided to field another experiment in Japan (hereafter, Study 2), an important U.S. ally in Asia. We also intend to undertake a multinational survey experiment (Study 3) in the future, for which we will submit another addendum. • At least in Study 2, we decided not to test Hypothesis 2, which is about the treatment effect on respondents’ belief in “shared values with the U.S.” Retrospectively, we should have considered this variable as a causal mediator. Namely, the exposure to information that U.S. democracy is reduced, which is our treatment variable, may affect whether foreign citizens think that they share many common values and ideals with Americans. Then, this sense of sharing values and ideals may affect whether foreign citizens trust the U.S. as an ally, which is the variable used to test Hypothesis 1. At least in Study 2, we do not undertake causal mediation analysis and focus on examining the treatment effects of the two fundamentally important variables: foreign citizens’ trust in, and perceived effectiveness of, the U.S. as an ally. • As we did not obtain clear patterns of conditional treatment effects (Hypotheses 4 and 5) in Study 1, we do not examine these effects in Study 2. This decision also derives from our concern that some pre-treatment attitudinal questions, such as respondents’ support for President Trump, may encourage them to provide consistent answers throughout the survey. For example, those who report that they do not support President Trump may also report that they do not trust the U.S. as an ally, regardless of our treatment assignment. This issue was less of a concern in Study 1 because we had a range of filler questions (for another experiment unrelated to our project) between the key pre-treatment questions and the treatment assignment. Study 2, however, is much shorter (about 3 minutes). Therefore, if we added these attitudinal questions, they could contaminate the treatment effects. • We rephrased and renumbered our hypotheses (see Section C2) and improved our experimental design in various ways (see Section C3).

q16.value: For Study 1, please refer to the original EGAP submission, which includes a pre- analysis plan. • In Study 2, we re-examine the following two hypotheses. Hypothesis 1 corresponds to Hypotheses 1a and 1b in Study 1. Hypothesis 2 corresponds to Hypotheses 3a and 3b in Study 1. • Hypothesis 1: Receiving information about the reduction of U.S. democracy will decrease foreign citizens’ belief that the U.S. is a trustworthy ally. We theorize that providing respondents with information that American democracy is in danger due to Russian election interference will reduce foreign citizens’ trust in the U.S. to fulfill its alliance commitment. Because common interests shared by democracies should constitute a foundation of the motivation for the alliance relationship, the logic goes, once this fundamental aspect of U.S. identity is reduced, citizens of allied democracies will also reduce their expectations that the U.S. will have an interest in defending other democracies. Trust is the central dynamic of a military alliance, since each party must trust the other to honor the agreement. Thus, we consider Hypothesis 1 as of the utmost importance for our study. • Hypothesis 2: Receiving information about Russian election interference will decrease foreign citizens’ belief that the U.S. is an effective ally. Providing information about Russian election interference in the U.S. might convey an impression of U.S. weakness to address external threats. If the U.S. cannot protect one of its core domestic institu- tions from interference by an adversary, its desirability as an ally on purely pragmatic terms might be questioned. A theoretically relevant concept here is effectiveness, which is slightly different from capability. The latter term may imply military strength (e.g., force structure and technical sophistication), rather than the organizational compe- tence and political will to use that strength. We think that the election interference would cast doubt on U.S. will and competence, but perhaps not on the narrow defini- tion of military capability. Effectiveness thus can be seen as a component of a broader conception of capability.

q17.value: For Study 1, please refer to the original EGAP submission, which includes a pre- analysis plan. • We will field a survey experiment using Lancers, a crowd-sourcing platform in Japan. The targeted participants are Japanese adult citizens. • After obtaining consent from participants, we ask four essential demographic questions. They include each respondent’s (1) highest level of educational attainment (elementary school or junior high school, high school, vocational school, junior college or technical junior college, university and/or graduate school); (2) gender (man, woman, other); (3) age group (18–25, 26–35, 36–45, 46–55, 56–65, 66 and over); and (4) current place of residence (Hokkaido, ... Okinawa, and a foreign country). • Based on these four variables, we make 13 strata. The first stratum includes respon- dents living in Okinawa. Because more than 60% of all U.S. bases in Japan are in Okinawa, citizens in Okinawa are expected to have different attitudes toward the al- liance with the U.S. Respondents in other parts of Japan are then divided into 12 strata = 2 (whether or not a respondent’s highest level of education is university or graduate school) × 2 (whether or not a respondent is a woman; respondents who report “other“ are randomly assigned to either “man” or “woman”) × 3 (whether or not a respondent’s age is 18–35, 36–45, or 45 or over). To improve efficiency in estimation, we will administer block randomization within each stratum. • Respondents are randomly divided into three groups: Control (p = 1/3), Treatment 1 (p = 1/3), and Treatment 2 (p = 1/3). Respondents in the control group are exposed to no information. Respondents in the two treatment groups are given information about the Russian election interference in recent U.S. elections. As in Study 1, Treat- ment 1 emphasizes that the interference reduced U.S. democracy, while Treatment 2 emphasizes that the interference did not reduce U.S. democracy. • After the treatment assignment, all respondents are asked the following questions in random order. To provide context, a prompt is added before these questions: Prompt “Please answer the following questions, assuming that attacks from other countries threaten Japan’s security and that the United States is expected to help defend Japan based on the Japan-US alliance.” Question 1 “Do you believe that the United States will keep its promise to defend Japan, or not?” Question 2 “Do you believe that the United States can defend Japan, or not?” • The numerical values are assigned to the outcome variables in the following way: Question 1 “I believe the U.S. will keep its promise” (4); “If anything, I believe the U.S. will keep its promise” (3); “If anything, I don’t believe the U.S. will keep its promise” (2); and “I don’t believe the U.S. will keep its promise” (1). Question 2 “I believe the U.S. can defend” (4); “If anything, I believe the U.S. can defend” (3); “If anything, I don’t believe that the U.S. can defend” (2); and “I don’t believe that the U.S. can defend” (1). • We ask one factual manipulation check question after the questions for our outcome variables. We ask this question to assess the quality of responses and interpret the nuanced effects of the treatment variables. The dependent variables are how much respondents believe that the U.S. is a trustworthy ally (Y1) and how much respondents believe that the U.S. is an effective ally (Y2). The independent variables are the dummy variables for Treatment 1 (T1) and Treatment 2 (T2). The baseline for the treatment variables is the control group. Y1 =b0 +b1 ·T1 +b2 ·T2 +u Y2 =c0 +c1 ·T1 +c2 ·T2 +v • Given Hypothesis 1, our expectation is that we reject the null hypothesis b1 = 0 and the null hypothesis b1 = b2 but fail to reject the null hypothesis b2 = 0. Given Hypothesis 2, our expectation is that we reject the null hypothesis c1 = 0 and the null hypothesis c2 = 0 but fail to reject the null hypothesis that c1 = c2. registration_responses.q15: For Study 1 (Australia and the U.K.), please refer to the original EGAP submission, which includes a pre-analysis plan. • After observing some promising results from the two survey experiments in Australia and the United Kingdom (hereafter, Study 1), we decided to field another experiment in Japan (hereafter, Study 2), an important U.S. ally in Asia. We also intend to undertake a multinational survey experiment (Study 3) in the future, for which we will submit another addendum. • At least in Study 2, we decided not to test Hypothesis 2, which is about the treatment effect on respondents’ belief in “shared values with the U.S.” Retrospectively, we should have considered this variable as a causal mediator. Namely, the exposure to information that U.S. democracy is reduced, which is our treatment variable, may affect whether foreign citizens think that they share many common values and ideals with Americans. Then, this sense of sharing values and ideals may affect whether foreign citizens trust the U.S. as an ally, which is the variable used to test Hypothesis 1. At least in Study 2, we do not undertake causal mediation analysis and focus on examining the treatment effects of the two fundamentally important variables: foreign citizens’ trust in, and perceived effectiveness of, the U.S. as an ally. • As we did not obtain clear patterns of conditional treatment effects (Hypotheses 4 and 5) in Study 1, we do not examine these effects in Study 2. This decision also derives from our concern that some pre-treatment attitudinal questions, such as respondents’ support for President Trump, may encourage them to provide consistent answers throughout the survey. For example, those who report that they do not support President Trump may also report that they do not trust the U.S. as an ally, regardless of our treatment assignment. This issue was less of a concern in Study 1 because we had a range of filler questions (for another experiment unrelated to our project) between the key pre-treatment questions and the treatment assignment. Study 2, however, is much shorter (about 3 minutes). Therefore, if we added these attitudinal questions, they could contaminate the treatment effects. • We rephrased and renumbered our hypotheses (see Section C2) and improved our experimental design in various ways (see Section C3).
registration_responses.q16: For Study 1, please refer to the original EGAP submission, which includes a pre- analysis plan. • In Study 2, we re-examine the following two hypotheses. Hypothesis 1 corresponds to Hypotheses 1a and 1b in Study 1. Hypothesis 2 corresponds to Hypotheses 3a and 3b in Study 1. • Hypothesis 1: Receiving information about the reduction of U.S. democracy will decrease foreign citizens’ belief that the U.S. is a trustworthy ally. We theorize that providing respondents with information that American democracy is in danger due to Russian election interference will reduce foreign citizens’ trust in the U.S. to fulfill its alliance commitment. Because common interests shared by democracies should constitute a foundation of the motivation for the alliance relationship, the logic goes, once this fundamental aspect of U.S. identity is reduced, citizens of allied democracies will also reduce their expectations that the U.S. will have an interest in defending other democracies. Trust is the central dynamic of a military alliance, since each party must trust the other to honor the agreement. Thus, we consider Hypothesis 1 as of the utmost importance for our study. • Hypothesis 2: Receiving information about Russian election interference will decrease foreign citizens’ belief that the U.S. is an effective ally. Providing information about Russian election interference in the U.S. might convey an impression of U.S. weakness to address external threats. If the U.S. cannot protect one of its core domestic institu- tions from interference by an adversary, its desirability as an ally on purely pragmatic terms might be questioned. A theoretically relevant concept here is effectiveness, which is slightly different from capability. The latter term may imply military strength (e.g., force structure and technical sophistication), rather than the organizational compe- tence and political will to use that strength. We think that the election interference would cast doubt on U.S. will and competence, but perhaps not on the narrow defini- tion of military capability. Effectiveness thus can be seen as a component of a broader conception of capability.

attributes.title: What Motivates Skilled Workers to Emigrate from Japan? An Experimental Investi- gation of Potential Brain Drain

q1.value: What Motivates Skilled Workers to Emigrate from Japan? An Experimental Investi- gation of Potential Brain Drain

q5.value: We thank the Japan Center for Economic Research for financial support.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Japan’s labor force population is predicted to decrease by nearly 40% between 2005 and 2050. Although the Japanese government has been promoting the acceptance of highly skilled foreign workers, the lack of skilled labor force in Japan is already at the critical level. Furthermore, the number of Japanese citizens moving overseas as permanent residents has been increasing, hitting a record high of 510,000 in 2018. What motivates Japanese people – particularly, skilled workers defined as those who have a university degree — to relocate to other countries permanently? What policies could encourage skilled workers to stay in Japan or to go back to Japan? As part of our research program aimed to understand demographic changes in Japan and their ramifications, we will field a survey experiment designed to test hypotheses regarding the factors that motivate Japanese skilled workers to emigrate to other countries.

q16.value: • We test the following main hypotheses using all valid respondents: Hypothesis 1: Japanese skilled workers are motivated to emigrate from Japan per- manently when they are exposed to information about the quality of life, which is reported to be better in foreign countries than in Japan. Hypothesis 2: Japanese skilled workers are motivated to emigrate from Japan per- manently when they are exposed to information about potential risk that Japanese economy and Japan’s natural environment are facing according to some reports. Hypothesis 3: The effect of exposure to information about the quality of life is smaller than the effect of exposure to information about risk. • In addition, we examine the following exploratory research questions (RQs). RQ 1: On Hypothesis 2, is the effect different depending on whether Japanese skilled workers are exposed to information about economic risk or about risk associated with natural environment? RQ 2: Are Japanese skilled workers with a child/children motivated to help their child/children to pursue a degree at a foreign university when they are exposed to information about the quality of life? RQ 3: Are Japanese skilled workers with a child/children motivated to help their child/children to pursue a degree at a foreign university when they are exposed to information about Japan’s risk? RQ 4: On Hypotheses 1–3, are the effects different depending on Japanese skilled workers’ age, gender, income level, whether they have a child/children or their prior experience of living abroad? RQ 5: On Hypotheses 1–3, are the effects different depending on Japanese skilled workers’ political attitudes (trust in government, frequency of voting in the past elections)?

q17.value: • We will field a survey experiment using Lancers, a crowd-sourcing platform in Japan. The targeted participants are Japanese adult citizens (and residents) with a university degree or a higher degree. • Based on pre-treatment demographic questions (specifically, age, gender, income, having a child/children or not, having lived abroad or not), we make 48 strata and administer block randomization within each stratum. • Respondents are randomly divided into three groups: Control (p = 1/3), Treatment 1 (p = 1/3), and Treatment 2 (p = 1/3). Respondents in the control group are exposed to no information. Respondents in the two treatment groups are given information about the quality of life in Japan (Treatment 1) or about Japan’s risk (Treatment 2). Furthermore, respondents in Treatment 2 are randomly and equally divided into two subgroups – those who are exposed to information about economic risk (Treatment 2a) and those who are exposed to information about risk associated with natural environment (Treatment 2b). • After the treatment assignment, all respondents are asked the following question: “Do you think that there is a possibility, in the future, that you will gather information and/or apply for jobs for the purpose of long-term immigration to foreign countries? (Note: Long-term immigration means living abroad for more than five years and includes the possibility of permanent residence in the future. However, overseas expatriates, such as intra-company transfer, are excluded.)” This first outcome variable is coded 1 if an answer is “Yes,” and 0 if an answer is “No.” • Respondents with a child/children are also asked the following questions: “Do you think there is a possibility, in the future, that you will gather information for the purpose of helping your child/children obtain a degree at an overseas university or graduate school?” The second outcome variable is coded 1 if the answer is “Yes,” and 0 if it is “No.” • We ask one factual manipulation check question after the questions for our outcome variables. We ask this question to assess the quality of responses and interpret the nuanced effects of the treatment variables. We do not make subsets of respondents based on this question for subgroup analysis. • We run OLS regression analysis with all valid responses to test Hypotheses 1–3. The baseline for the treatment variables is the control group. The independent variables are the dummy variables for Treatment 1 and Treatment 2. We estimate the average treatment effects (to test Hypotheses 1 and 2) with and without using a set of dummy variables for the pre-stratified blocks. The difference in the two treatment effects (to test Hypothesis 3) is also tested statistically. • To examine RQ 1, we repeat the above procedure with three (instead of two) dummy variables for Treatment 1, Treatment 2a, and Treatment 2b. The difference in the treatment effect of economic risk and the treatment effect of risk associated with natural environment is tested statistically. • Similarly, we run OLS regression analysis with all respondents with at least one child to examine RQ 2 and RQ 3. The baseline for the treatment variables is the control group and the model includes two dummy variables for Treatment 1 and Treatment 2 or three dummy variables for Treatment 1, Treatment 2a and Treatment 2b. We estimate the average treatment effects with and without using a set of dummy variables for the pre- stratified blocks. The differences between pairs of coefficients are tested statistically. • To examine RQ 4 and RQ 5, we estimate treatment effect heterogeneity using pre-treatment variables, including the variables used to make the randomized blocks and the questions about respondents’ trust in government and their frequency of voting in the past elections.

q25.value: July 22, 2019 (Dartmouth College); March 12, 2019 (The University of Melbourne)

attributes.title: Public Opinion on Politician Incivility & Apologies in the United States

q1.value: Public Opinion on Politician Incivility & Apologies in the United States

q5.value: We thank the Lucas Family Fund for Undergraduate Research from the Office of Under- graduate Advising and Research at Dartmouth College, the Nelson A. Rockefeller Center for Public Policy at Dartmouth College, , the Thomas D. Sayles Research Grant from the Ethics Institute at Dartmouth College, and the Quantitative Social Science Program at Dartmouth College for support., We would also like to thank Kotaro Horiuchi and Leeya Kekona for com- ments on uncivil statements, and Professor Jeremy Ferwerda for comments on the research design.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Conversations among politicians are often heated and passionate, but sometimes politicians cross the line of civility: they make “comments that convey an unnecessarily disrespectful tone toward the discussion forum, its respondents, or its topics” (Coe, Kenski, and Rains 2014). While some large political figures, such as President Trump, often ignore and even bash a harsh backlash from the media and public opinion to their uncivil comments, other politicians apologize after making these comments. For example, a candidate for Arizona’s first Congressional District apologized for saying “99 percent of (mass shootings) have been by Democrats pulling their guns out and shooting people” (Press 2014). Another political candidate, who was running for the North Carolina state House, apologized after an old expletive-filled rant on Mexicans she made surfaced (Specht 2018). However, how much do these apologies matter? Past studies in political science and psychology find that anger expression and incivility are not effective as a persuasion tactic, and can even cause politicians to be viewed less favorably and as unfriendly and incompetent (Brooks and Geer 2007; Brooks 2011; Riet, Schaap, and Kleemans 2018). These reactions are also nuanced: according to Brooks (2011), Druckman et al. (2018), and Eggers, Vivyan, and Wagner (2017), the identities of a politician and a respondent can affect how the respondent reacts to the politician’s actions and words. However, no study has yet to examine how people react when politicians apologize for their uncivil comments, compared to when they ignore criticism by the media and the public. Do these apologies affect voters’ evaluations of and their response to the politicians in general? Also, do the genders of politicians and voters interactively influence the voters’ evaluations of and responses to the politicians?

q16.value: We test the following hypotheses: Hypothesis 1a: People will evaluate a politician who makes an uncivil comment worse than a politician who does not make an uncivil comment. Hypothesis 1b: Women will evaluate a female politician who makes an uncivil comment worse than a male politician who makes the same comment. Hypothesis 2a: People will evaluate a politician who makes an uncivil comment worse than a politician who makes the same uncivil comment and apologizes. Hypothesis 2b: Women will evaluate a female politician who makes an uncivil comment and apologizes worse than a male politician who apologizes for the same comment. Hypothesis 3a: People exposed to an uncivil comment by a politician will write more about how they feel about the topic and the politician than people not exposed to an uncivil comment. Hypothesis 3b: People exposed to an uncivil comment by a politician will be more likely to have an angry tone when writing about how they feel about the topic and the politician than people not exposed to an uncivil comment. Hypothesis 4: The effects of uncivil communications (specifically, Hypotheses 1a, 2a, 3a, and 3b) will be smaller for conflict-seeking individuals compared to conflict-avoidant individuals. In addition to our confirmatory analysis to test these hypotheses, we will undertake a range of exploratory analysis. The research questions (RQs) include the following: RQ1: Will people evaluate a politician who makes an uncivil comment and apologizes worse than a politician who does not make an uncivil comment? RQ2: Will people react to politicians differently given the interaction of topics (gendered or ungendered) and the politician’s gender? RQ3a: Will people write less about how they feel about the topic and the politician when they are exposed to an uncivil comment with an apology compared to when they are exposed to an uncivil comment without an apology? RQ3b: Will people have an angrier tone when writing about how they feel about the topic and the politician when they are exposed to an uncivil comment with an apology compared to when they are exposed to an uncivil comment without an apology? RQ4a: Will women write less about how they feel about the topic and the politician if the politician is a woman compared to if the politician is a man. RQ4b: Will women have an angrier tone when writing about how they feel about the topic and the politician if the politician is a woman compared to if the politician is a man. RQ5: Will men react differently to an uncivil comment or an uncivil comment with an apology from a female politician compared to a male politician? RQ6: Will men and women evaluate politicians differently based on their own gender and the gender of the politician? RQ7: Will these effects be different by people’s partisanship?

q17.value: We will conduct a randomized survey experiment to test these hypotheses and examine exploratory research questions. Participants will be United States citizens, who are 18 years old or older, and recruited through the Qualtrics Panel. We will conduct analyses using all respondents, as well as some subgroups of respondents. See the attached appendix for the survey instruments and our plan of statistical analysis.

RQ6: Will men and women evaluate politicians differently based on their own gender and the gender of the politician? RQ7: Will these effects be different by people’s partisanship?
registration_responses.q17: We will conduct a randomized survey experiment to test these hypotheses and examine exploratory research questions. Participants will be United States citizens, who are 18 years old or older, and recruited through the Qualtrics Panel. We will conduct analyses using all respondents, as well as some subgroups of respondents. See the attached appendix for the survey instruments and our plan of statistical analysis.

q15.value: Immigration is becoming a more divisive and contentious topic in American politics. While Republicans and Democrats were equally likely to support decreasing legal immigration to the U.S. in 2006, Republicans are now twice as likely as Democrats to favor decreasing legal immigration (Pew Research Center 2018). Additionally, a recent poll shows that 30 percent of Americans support President Trump’s immigration policies, 38 percent support the immigration policies of Democrats in Congress, and 24 percent support neither (The Washington Post 2018). The partisan division on the issue also increased over the past decade. While 49 percent of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents feel “unsympathetic” toward undocumented immigrants, only 13 percent of Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents harbor the same attitude (Pew Research Center 2018). Despite the politicization of this topic, Hainmueller and Hopkins (2015) find evidence of a consensus on the type of immigrants American prefer. It is unclear, however, whether they have a similar consensual view on immigration policies. To address this, we conduct a conjoint survey experiment (Hainmueller, Hopkins, and Yamamoto 2014) with immigra- tion policy issues currently debated in American politics as attribute-levels. In addition, we include a component of randomized framing treatment in the survey to examine the effects of framing on immigration policy preferences. The survey experiment and its associated analyses provide an understanding as to what form of immigration policy individuals would support, what attributes are salient in this decision, whether framing affects this level of support, and whether preference and the effect of framing differ by the attributes of respondents.

q16.value: We aim to test three hypotheses and five research questions (RQs) through a conjoint analysis survey experiment with a randomized assignment of framing treatments. Hypothesis 1 For each immigration policy issue, respondents have stronger preferences for policies that are more favorable toward immigrants than those that are less favorable. Hypothesis 2 Across all immigration policy issues, border detainment is the most salient for respondents. Hypothesis 3 Compared to the case in which “unauthorized immigrants” is used, respon- dents have stronger preferences for policies unfavorable to immigrants when “illegal aliens” is used and stronger preferences for policies favorable to immigrants when “undocumented immigrants” is used. RQ 1 How do preferences for immigration policies differ depending on respondent charac- teristics? RQ 2 How does framing change immigration policy preferences depending on respondent characteristics? RQ 3 How do preferences (and differences in preferences) differ depending on how prefer- ence is quantified? RQ 4 How do preferences for a specific attribute level change depending on the other at- tribute levels included in the proposal? RQ 5 How do expectations about perceived crime rates and education attainment change depending on framing treatment and respondent attribute? – How much do respondents respond to framing treatments depending on their own attributes?

q17.value: To test the hypotheses and research questions, we conduct a conjoint analysis survey exper- iment with randomized treatment assignments. We conduct group and sub-group analyses. See the attached for the survey design and plan of statistical analysis.
